reviewText: This is one of the easiest/hardest RTS i've ever played. once the game gets going it can easly get flipped really quick. so much fun and Pwnee is going to be making new game modes and possibliy more players. if youre new to RTS's give it a try or even RTS veterns give it a try. When it comes to this game youre more of a general commanding massive numbers rather then just selecting a handful of guys and telling them to attack. This game makes really easy to attack since there is auto attack. overall extremely just be careful starting a match because your ideal 30 minute match could become 2 hours. have fun.

reviewText:
I absolutely love this game.

At first, I thought it was just another 2D RTS game that had really bad graphics.  After playing a session for like an hour or so though, I love the concept.  They made an RTS game that is as minimal as possible.  Literally zero options for units, buildings, or anything of that sort.  You just have a barracks that automatically spews out enemies and you place gold mines on gold mines to generate money.  The Jade system is basically a special currency of special weapons.  You need it to cast nukes and such.  Harvested exactly the same as gold, you place little jade harvesters on jade mines.

You have the ability to send 1000's of units into battle at once.  The game is all about volume and strategy.  Your unit creating barracks will automatically send them to a desired waypoint, so you can literally create 100's of barracks all over the map and send them to your enemies bases or you could try to surround your enemy with barracks so they are just getting infinitely bombarded.  And you will have armies to face as well.  The sheer numbers of units you will be using is so entertaining.  It would be too complicated to have direct control on any of them so it's great how you can just focus on setting the waypoints to your battles so the fresh units will be at the right place.  You could also build up an army of a  zillion units to send in all at once and overwhelm them.

I only played one match so far but I plan on playing the game a lot more often, I just wanted to post my thoughts here.  It's not a game I could see growing old anytime soon since it's so shallow there isn't much to get bored of right off the bat, but no other game I have played uses these very simple rules with insane numbers.  It instantly became one of my favorite RTS's of all time in a very short period of time.

Something you notice early on is that the cost of each barrack or gold mine increases with each one added.  Also, the amount of jade required for a nuke (or any other ability) increases with each use.  This helps to bring balance to the game over periods of time!

There are some aspects I would like improved, but the main drawback is that the pathfinding is not very bright.  Sometimes the units get confused and just stop.  Or one prime example is I had a barracks creating units and sending them across the map to the north-east but 20% of the units created were being sent into a corner and pooling up for no apparent reason, even if I changed the waypoint they kept just leaking out into the corner (in the complete opposite direction).  That being said though, for something this indie"
date: they have created something very unique and worth checking out."

reviewText: I saw this game at RTX 2015 over the past weekend and the first thing that really drew me in were the developers that were working at the booth. They were just really chill people who were stoked about the game, that excitement quickly rubbed off on me and I was ready to try it out. My first game didn't go so well as I was bum-rushed by another player before I had the chance to get my dragonlord out of the way. Second game, much better. I believe that it was the first coop game setup at RTX 2015 so that was pretty cool. I was playing along side my friend against two people who had just met, obvious advantage, right? Wrong. It started out with my friend on the top left quadrant and me on the bottom left quadrant. We both fought battles to our right first of all and it just so happened that I was paired with the more capable enemy out of the two. My friend had already won his battle and half of the enemy team was taken out shortly after the start of the game. I wasnt't too far behind him in my defeat so I reverted to defensive strategies and attempted to transport my dragonlord up to where my friend was located. The remaining enemy got a little too close to my confused dragonlord and defeated me. It was up to my friend. The game went on a little longer and then we recieved guidance from a great source named John." It started out with John saying to my friend something along the lines of
date: "So you want to wipe out the pink?" Pink being the enemy of course
recommended: the answer was obviously yes. John told my friend to sit tight and build up jade which didnt't take long
hoursPlayed: then he pointed out the enemy dragonlord on his corner with a not-so-big army gaurding his dragonlord. John instructed my friend to use a strategy that was very familiar to him that hadn't crossed either of our minds. My friend used Terracotta
voteText: it was super effective! A well placed Terracotta wiped out an enemy that was easily winning the battle in troop count and brought us to victory. Thank you
helpfulPercent: John! The four of us at the table were all fairly surprised at the outcome and high-fives were shared amongst us. My friend and I then split the cost of four copies
votesHelpful: with the intentions of giving away the other two copies to our friends. After downloading it on my PC and having a chance to experience it more
votesTotal: I really like the community that I've seen so far and have throughly enjoyed playing the game with people that I met less than an hour earlier. Overall
commentsCount: and I hope that the community will grow and give it support so that it can be even better."

reviewText:
The only reason this review is negative is because the developer seems to have abandoned this promising title.

TL;DR: The game is fun, but it's limited to multiplayer. Wait till the devs start updating it again before you buy it.

Some friends and I bought this game after talking to the devs and seeing gameplay at RTX 2015, and it seemed absolutely worth it. Aside from some initial technical difficulties (which were quickly fixed by the devs within a day of us bringing it to their attention) they game was really fun. It's fun to play, has decent music, and functioning multiplayer. Unfortunately, that’s essentially as far as it goes. There isn't really any single player aside from the training maps, but those are essentially just you trying to build up your army fast enough to not be overwhelmed by the preplaced enemy buildings. There is no AI that tries to out build you or gather more resources or anything of that nature, so the only real strategical matches you'll play in this game will be in multiplayer. Nonetheless, if you have someone to play with, then you'll have a good time.
Also, after launch the devs added a Map Editor" feature that allows you to design your own scenarios and maps (much like the scenario editor in Rise of Nations). This is a great addition; however
date: you cannot use the custom maps in multiplayer matches. Thus
recommended: the feature is somewhat worthless considering the lack of a single player AI.\nHonestly
hoursPlayed: this game feels like it should have been an early access release considering the sheer lack of features. And like many early access releases
voteText: the developers stopped pumping out patches and additions in September.\nOverall
helpfulPercent: I wouldn’t buy this game unless it is heavily discounted or the changelogs reveal some more recent updates.\n"

reviewText:
If you love board games, such as Risk, or are even a fan of old-school RTS games like Rise of Nations, you should definitely pick up this game.

WAL is a game of war in which the overall battle can change in seconds. You start out with a Dragon Lord (General), and possibly a handful of troops, and start out to build Gold Factories and Jade Factories where the resources can be found. You use Gold to build more factories as well as barracks. Jade is gathered so the Dragon Lord can cast spells to harm your opponnent/strengthen your position. The sole purpose of Barracks is to continuously and indefinitely pump out soldiers at no further cost to you. The more barracks you have, the quicker you can build an unstoppable legion. And from there, use your wits and strategize against your opponents.

Overall, WAL is a great RTS game to play either solo or with friends.  So what are you waiting for? Play it!

reviewText:
Cool game and idea. If you don't have friends to play with the game will get old quick though.


Game needs a big content update and features such as:

-Steam workshop
-Achievements Preferably
-Walls/Defensive Structures?
-Gamemodes.
-More types of melee units. More expensive barracks that spawn slower but give stronger units. Or even have certain units combat other types more effectivly.
-Higher player count
-Upgrade system
-Ranged Units
-Cannons?
-Water? Perhaps there could be a bridge system to bottleneck combat.
-Boats/Ships?
-New types of Resources?
Possibilitys are unless.

This game also needs a 4 pack to become more economically viable.

If they game gets support from the devs and a playerbase it'll be great.

recommended:

reviewText: Super fun for fans of war and strategy games, it is simple in that you can easily throw yourself into the game, but complex because of the fact that so much is happening in such a short amount of time. reviewText:
Wonderful idea, wrong price.
I can't do much complaining because I got this game as part of a $3 bundle on INDIEGALA, but NO WAY is this game worth $15 in its current state. There is very little content. Online doesn't even exist because nobody plays this game. (Maybe because it's fifteen freakin' dollars for an 8-bit RTS with two major components)
Barracks: Spawns units endlessly
Resource sites (2 types): Spawns money endlessly
All that's left to do is send unit A to enemy A and unit B to enemy B and watch.

I'll admit it was fun for a while, but I can't recommend this game in its current state.

So i played a little the training map and i don't regret any single cent of the indiegala's bundle i just bought with two key of the game and a bunch of other games for 3 euros(14.99 is a little too much you should reduce the price).
The game is amazingly fun and the idea is original and i like the desing of the units and buildings too(2d rocks as always :D)but i also think that you should work on it a lot more for make it really good:
-You should think about adding singleplayer with skirmish and campaign mode because when im alone in training mode the AI have no brain at all and you can win too easy,yeah i know that i can search a game online for a challenge but think about it for a sec=what if one day you can't mantain servers anymore?All players stuck in the training map with the AI or with some luck playing LAN with their friends so please think about it.

date: you should add some new musics.\n-You should also think about adding ranged units and artillery units
recommended: the game would be more realistic and would give a real sense of total warfare

reviewText:
I'm gonna say right off the bat: this isn't a game for everyone. For those who like slow and strategic rts games, this probably won't be the game for you. It also isn't very good when it comes to online play, as it's just kind of boring. But if you're looking for a good, short, and exciting game to play with your friends, this games is perfect for you. The massive scale and and endless battle possibilites give it endless replayability, and even plaaying it with just three friends can be fun.


In short, its a nice little game to play if you and your friends want a quick little bit of excitement.
